title: Ticket #4819: "queue" for multiple files
description:
One of the most common user questions we get is "how do I process a directory of files?" Sadly, there's no answer that doesn't involve a perl script.

We should introduce some new semantics for the "queue" command in condor_submit files. Currently, 

queue N

Means to queue N jobs, with $(Process) expanding to values 0 through N-1.

The expanded queue syntax will be one of the following 

queue [<int-expr>] [<v>] in <itemlist>
queue [<int-expr>] [<v>] matching <globlist>
queue [<int-expr>] [<v1>,<v2>,...] from <itemfile>

where []   indicates optional parts of the syntax.
<int-expr> is an expression evaluating to an integer
<v>        is a submit variable name to be used as the loop variable
<itemlist> is a list of comma and/or spaces separated literals
<globlist> is a list of comma and/or space separated glob patterns.
<itemfile> is the name of a file, - indicates stdin. each line of the file will be tokenized
           and used to set values for loop variables <v1>,<v2>,etc

  • if <itemlist> or <globlist> begins with '(' then the list continues until ')' even if the closing ')' is on another line. For multi-line lists, a leading '#' can be used to comment out lines, and line continuation using '\' is supported. (i.e. these lines follow the same rules as other lines in the submit file.)
  • if <itemfile> begins with '(' then the content of the itemfile is read from the submit file until the closing '). (this behavior is sometimes called a herefile).
  • if <itemfile> ends with '|', then it run as a command and it's stdout taken as the file content.

design doc here: https://docs.google.com/a/wisc.edu/document/d/10UKaiu1BkirXP6qUmx9DyEOPPSNqKqmS-2foztKi_zU/edit#

remarks:
2015-Feb-01 00:00:01 by bbockelm:
[Proposed this to tannenba last year at CERN, but I believe I failed to capture it in a ticket until now - please let me know if it's a dup.] 

queue for FILE matching file1, file2, dir1, dir2, glob1, ...

Here, we queue a job for matching files, with $(FILE) expanding to the filename that will be copied into the job's working directory. The file is added to the transfer_input_files. I propose the following semantics:

  • For a filename, we create one job specifically for that file.
  • For a directory, we create on job and transfer the whole directory. Trailing slash semantics are identical to those for transfer_input_files.
  • For a glob, we create a job for all matching files and directories.

Second: 

queue for FILE in dir1, dir2, dir3

This is similar to "matching" above, except that we recurse into directories and create a job for each file in a given directory (including sub-directories). As with LOCAL_CONFIG_DIR_EXCLUDE_REGEXP, we could have SUBMIT_FILE_EXCLUDE_REGEXP that would default to ignoring any vim / emacs temporary files and hidden files.

For each job, we also expand $(Process) to be the proc id; however, we make no guarantees on the ordering - we do not sort files (ALTERNATE: sort according to filename).

2015-Mar-31 09:56:56 by johnkn:
Note: in 8.3.5 on Windows the globbing does not support globbing of both file and directory at the same time - so 

    Queue matching */*.dat

does not work.
